VectorField.pm

00001 
00002 =head1 NAME
00003 
00004     VectorField
00005 
00006 =head1 SYNPOSIS
00007 
00008     use Carp;
00009     use GD;
00010     use WWPlot;
00011     use Fun;
00012     $fn = new Fun( rule_reference);
00013     $fn = new Fun( rule_reference , graph_reference);
00014     $fn = new Fun ( x_rule_ref, y_rule_ref );
00015     $fn = new Fun ( x_rule_ref, y_rule_ref, graph_ref );
00016 
00017 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00018 
00019 This module defines a phase plane vector field.  It can also be used to define direction fields
00020 for differenential equations.
00021 
00022 The following functions are provided:
00023 
00024 =head2  new  (direction field version)
00025 
00026 =over 4
00027 
00028 =item   $fn = new VectorField( dy_rule_ref);
00029 
00030 rule_reference is a reference to a subroutine which accepts a pair of numerical values
00031 and returns a numerical value.
00032 The Fun object will draw the direction field associated with this subroutine.
00033 
00034 The new method returns a reference to the vector field object.
00035 
00036 =item   $fn = new Fun( rule_reference , graph_reference);
00037 
00038 The vector field is also placed into the printing queue of the graph
00039  object pointed to by graph_reference and the
00040 domain of the vector field object is set to the domain of the graph.
00041 
00042 =back
00043 
00044 =head2  new  (phase plane version)
00045 
00046 =over 4
00047 
00048 =item   $fn = new VectorField ( dx_rule_ref, dy_rule_ref );
00049 
00050 A vector field object is created where the subroutines refered to by dx_rule_ref and dy_rule_ref define
00051 the x and y components of the vector field at (x,y).  Both subroutines must be functions of two variables.
00052 
00053 =item   $fn = new VectorField ( x_rule_ref, y_rule_ref, graph_ref );
00054 
00055 This variant inserts the vector field object into the graph object referred to by graph_ref.  The domain
00056 of the vector field object is set to the domain of the graph.
00057 
00058 =back
00059 
00060 =head2 Properites
00061 
00062     All of the properties are set using the construction $new_value = $fn->property($new_value)
00063     and read using $current_value = $fn->property()
00064 
00065 =over 4
00066 
00067 =item xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax
00068 
00069 The domain of the vector field defined by these values.
00070 
00071 =item x_steps y_steps
00072 
00073 This gives the number of intervals in the x direction (respectively the y direction) for plotting the vector
00074 field arrows.
00075 
00076 =item arrow_color, dot_color
00077 
00078 The colors of the arrow bodies and the dot "base" of the arrow are
00079  specified by a word such as 'orange' or 'yellow'.
00080 C<$vf->arrow_color('blue'); $vf->dot_color('red');> sets the drawing color to blue for the arrow body, with
00081 a red dot at the base of the arrow.  The RGB values for the color are defined in the graph
00082 object in which the vector field is drawn.  If the color, e.g. 'mauve', is not defined by the graph object
00083 then the function is drawn using the color 'default_color' which is always defined (and usually black).
00084 
00085 =item dx_rule
00086 
00087 A reference to the subroutine used to calculate the dx value of the phase plane field.
00088 This is set to the constant function 1
00089 when using the function object in direction field mode.
00090 
00091 =item dy_rule
00092 
00093 A reference to the subroutine used to calculate the dy value of the phase plane field.
00094 
00095 =item arrow_weight, dot_weight
00096 
00097 The width in pixels of the pen used to draw the arrow (respectively the dot).
00098 
00099 =back
00100 
00101 =head2 Actions which affect more than one property.
00102 
00103 =over 4
00104 
00105 
00106 =item domain
00107 
00108 $array_ref = $fn->domain(-1,-2,1,2) sets xmin to -1, ymin to -2, xmax to 1, and ymax to 2.
00109 
00110 
00111 =item draw
00112 
00113 $fn->draw($graph_ref) draws the vector field in the graph object pointed to by $graph_ref.
00114 
00115 The graph object must
00116 respond to the methods below.  The draw call is mainly for internal
00117 use by the graph object. Most users will not
00118 call it directly.
00119 
00120 =over 4
00121 
00122 =item   $graph_ref->{colors}
00123 
00124 a hash containing the defined colors
00125 
00126 =item $graph_ref ->im
00127 
00128 a GD image object
00129 
00130 =item $graph_ref->lineTo(x,y, color_number)
00131 
00132 draw line to the point (x,y) from the current position using the specified color.  To obtain the color number
00133 use a construction such as C<$color_number = $graph_ref->{colors}{'blue'};>
00134 
00135 =item $graph_ref->lineTo(x,y,gdBrushed)
00136 
00137 draw line to the point (x,y) using the pattern set by SetBrushed (see GD documentation)
00138 
00139 =item $graph_ref->moveTo(x,y)
00140 
00141 set the current position to (x,y)
00142 
00143 =back
00144 
00145 =back
00146 
00147 =cut
00148

00151 }

00153 package VectorField;

00163 @VectorField::ISA = qw(WWPlot);
00164 # import gdBrushed from GD.  It unclear why, but a good many global methods haven't been imported.
00165 sub gdBrushed {
00166     &GD::gdBrushed();
00167 }
00168 
00169 my $GRAPH_REFERENCE = "WWPlot";
00170 my $VECTORFIELD_REFERENCE = "VectorField";
00171 
00172 my %fields =(
00173         xmin            =>  -4,
00174         xmax            =>  4,
00175         ymin            =>  -4,
00176         ymax            =>   4,
00177         x_steps         =>  10,
00178         y_steps         =>  10,
00179         arrow_color     =>  'blue',
00180         arrow_weight    =>  1,  #line thickness
00181         dot_color       =>  'red',
00182         dot_radius      =>  1.5,
00183         dt              =>  0.1,
00184         dx_rule         => sub{1;},
00185         dy_rule         => sub{1;},
00186         rf_arrow_length => sub{my($dx,$dy)=@_;
00187                                    return(0) if sqrt($dx**2 + $dy**2) ==0;
00188                                    0.5*1/sqrt($dx**2 + $dy**2);
00189                               },
00190 
00191 );
00192 
00193 
00194 sub new {
00195     my $class               =   shift;
00196 
00197     my $self            = {
00198                 %fields,
00199     };
00200 
00201     bless $self, $class;
00202     $self -> _initialize(@_);
00203     return $self;
00204 }
00205 
00206 sub identity {  # the identity function
00207     shift;
00208 }
00209 
00210 
00211 sub _initialize {
00212     my  $self   =   shift;
00213     my  ($xrule,$yrule, $rule,$graphRef);
00214     my @input = @_;
00215     if (ref($input[$#input]) eq $GRAPH_REFERENCE ) {
00216         $graphRef = pop @input;  # get the last argument if it refers to a graph.
00217         $graphRef->fn($self);    # Install this vector field in the graph.
00218         $self->{xmin} = $graphRef->{xmin};
00219         $self->{xmax} = $graphRef->{xmax};
00220         $self->{ymin} = $graphRef->{ymin};
00221         $self->{ymax} = $graphRef->{ymax};
00222     }
00223     if ( @input == 1 ) {        # only one argument left -- this is a non parametric function
00224         $rule = $input[0];
00225         if ( ref($rule) eq $VECTORFIELD_REFERENCE ) {  # clone another function
00226             my $k;
00227             foreach $k (keys %fields) {
00228                 $self->{$k} = $rule->{$k};
00229             }
00230         } else {
00231             $self->{dx_rule} = sub {1; };
00232             $self->{dy_rule} = $input[0] ;
00233         }
00234     } elsif (@input == 2 ) {   #  two arguments -- parametric functions
00235             $self->{dx_rule} = $input[0] ;
00236             $self->{dy_rule} = $input[1] ;
00237 
00238     } else {
00239         die "VectorField.pm:_initialize: Can't call VectorField with more than two arguments";
00240     }
00241 }
00242 sub draw {
00243     my $self = shift;  # this function
00244     my $g = shift;   # the graph containing the function.
00245     warn "This vector field is not being called from an enclosing graph" unless defined($g);
00246     my $arrow_color;   # get color scheme from graph
00247     if ( defined( $g->{'colors'}{$self->arrow_color} )  ) {
00248         $arrow_color = $g->{'colors'}{$self->arrow_color};
00249     } else {
00250         $arrow_color = $g->{'colors'}{'blue'};  # what you do if the color isn't there
00251     }
00252     my $dot_color = $self ->dot_color;  # colors are defined differently for Circles, then for lines.
00253     my $dot_radius  = $self->dot_radius;
00254     my $brush = new GD::Image($self->arrow_weight,$self->arrow_weight);
00255     my $brush_color = $brush->colorAllocate($g->im->rgb($arrow_color));  # transfer color
00256     $g->im->setBrush($brush);
00257         my $x_steps = $self->x_steps;
00258     my $xmin = $self->xmin;
00259     my $x_stepsize = ( $self->xmax - $self->xmin )/$x_steps;
00260     my $y_steps = $self->y_steps;
00261     my $ymin = $self->ymin;
00262     my $y_stepsize = ( $self->ymax - $self->ymin )/$y_steps;
00263     my $dt = $self->dt;
00264     my $rf_arrow_length = $self->rf_arrow_length;
00265 
00266     foreach my $i (0..$x_steps) {
00267         my $x = $xmin + $i*$x_stepsize;
00268         foreach my $j (0..$y_steps) {
00269             my $y = $ymin + $j*$y_stepsize;
00270             my $dx = $dt*&{$self->dx_rule}($x,$y);
00271             my $dy = $dt*&{$self->dy_rule}($x,$y);
00272             $g->moveTo($x,$y);
00273             $g->stamps(new Circle($x, $y, $dot_radius,$dot_color,$dot_color) ) if $dot_radius > 0; 
00274                 # setting the radius to zero omits the dot
00275             $g->lineTo($x+$dx*&$rf_arrow_length($dx,$dy), $y+$dy*&$rf_arrow_length($dx,$dy),gdBrushed);
00276 
00277         }
00278     }
00279 }
00280 
00281 sub domain {
00282     my $self =shift;
00283     my @inputs = @_;
00284     $self->{xmin} = $inputs[0];
00285     $self->{ymin} = $inputs[1];
00286     $self->{xmax} = $inputs[2];
00287     $self->{ymax} = $inputs[3];
00288 }

00294     my $self = shift;

00296     unless (exists $self->{ymin} ) {
00297         die "Can't find ymin field in object of class $type";
00298     }
00299     
00300     if (@_) {
00301         return $self->{ymin} = shift;

00304     }
